newsitem.title: USA: Searchers comb mountainside for Air Force wreckage.
newsitem.headline: Searchers comb mountainside for Air Force wreckage.

text.p: Rescue workers combed a mountainside near Vail, Colorado for the second day on Tuesday searching for bombs and clues to explain why an Air Force warplane crashed into a mountain in April, an official said.

Capt. Craig Button disappeared April 2 during a routine training mission from Davis-Monthan Air Force Base in Arizona. The wreckage of his plane was not discovered until April 20. Heavy snow in the area forced the delay of rescue work until summer.

"We want to make the site safe for the public," said Air Force spokeswoman Capt. Robyn Chumley. Gold Dust Peak, where the wreckage was found, is in a very remote area 15 miles southwest of the ski resort of Vail. The U.S. Forest Service cordoned off the area.
The cause of the accident and why Button veered off course have still not been determined, Chumley said.
Human remains believed to be Button's were found Monday. Four 500-pound MC 82 bombs have not yet been located, she said.
The rescue work is expected to take around three weeks.
Besides the bombs, munitions workers also hope to bring back magnesium flares believed to have been on the A-10 warplane, she said.
